History. Laws 1991, ch. 222, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 9-2-2009 ; 2003, ch. 127, § 1; 2007, ch. 215, § 1; 2008, ch. 44, § 1; 2013, ch. 155, § 1; 2021, ch. 56, § 3.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, in (a) substituted “9-2-1707” for “9-2-1708.”

Laws 2007, ch. 215, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved July 1, 2007.

The 2008 amendment, in (b), deleted “not later than July 1, 1990” at the end of the first sentence, and deleted the former second through sixth sentences pertaining to various reporting requirements to the legislature and legislative committees.

Laws 2008, ch. 44, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2008.

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, added (e) to (h).

The 2021 amendment, in (d), substituted "9-2-1001.1" for "9-2-1001" and "9-2-1014.2" for "9-2-1026."

Laws 2021, ch. 56, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved April 1, 2021.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2007, ch. 215, § 4, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Laws 2008, ch. 44, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Editor’s notes. —

Laws 2013, ch. 155, § 2, directs: “The director of the office of state lands, in consultation with the directors of the departments of corrections, family services and health shall submit a report to the board of land commissioners and the joint minerals, business and economic development interim committee identifying lands that will be managed by the board of land commissioners pursuant to this act by October 1, 2013. The report shall also identify the potential best use for each managed property consistent with the management considerations required by this act.”

§ 9-2-2013. Department of environmental quality created; director appointed; structure.

  1. As part of the reorganization of Wyoming state government, there is created the department of environmental quality consisting of the existing state department of environmental quality, the state office of industrial siting administration and the industrial siting council. Except for the existing environmental quality council, which shall not be within the department of environmental quality but shall be a separate operating agency, and those programs or functions specified by law to be performed by another entity all programs and functions specified in chapters 11 and 12 of title 35 shall be with the department of environmental quality. Except for W.S. 9-2-1703(a)(v) and (ix), the limitation of number of principal departments contained in W.S. 9-2-1703(a)(iii), 9-2-1704(a) and (b), 9-2-1706(c)(i)(D) and 9-2-1707 (a)(iii) and (iv), the provisions of the Wyoming Government Reorganization Act of 1989, W.S. 9-2-1701 through 9-2-1707 , apply to this section.
  2. The administrative head of the department shall be a director who shall serve at the pleasure of the governor and may be removed by him as provided in W.S. 9-1-202 . The director shall be appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the senate.
  3. The department shall not be subject to a transition period as defined in W.S. 9-2-1703(a)(ix). A reorganization plan shall not be required of the director.

History. Laws 1992, ch. 60, § 2; 2007, ch. 215, § 1.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, in (a) substituted “9-2-1707” for “9-2-1708.”

Laws 2007, ch. 215, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved July 1, 2007.

Editor's notes. —

Laws 1992, chs. 42 and 55, also enacted a § 9-2-2013 . See §§ 9-2-2014 and 9-2-2015 and notes thereto.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2007, ch. 215, § 4, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

§ 9-2-2014. Wyoming water development office created; director appointed; structure.

  1. As part of the reorganization of Wyoming state government there is created the Wyoming water development office consisting of the programs and functions specified in this section.
  2. The administrative head of the office shall be a director appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the senate. The director shall serve at the pleasure of the governor and may be removed by the governor as provided in W.S. 9-1-202 . The director’s term of appointment shall expire at the end of the term of office of the governor during which he was appointed, unless sooner removed.
  3. The Wyoming water development office shall consist of the Wyoming water development commission, staff and programs.

History. Laws 1992, ch. 42, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 9-2-2013 .

Editor's notes. —

This section was enacted as § 9-2-2013 . As a § 9-2-2013 was also enacted by Laws 1992, chs. 55 and 60, this section has been redesignated as § 9-2-2014 . See, also, §§ 9-2-2013 and 9-2-2015 and notes thereto.

§ 9-2-2015. Office of state lands and investments; director appointed; structure.

  1. As part of the reorganization of Wyoming state government there is created the state land and farm loan office consisting of the programs and functions specified in this section. From and after April 1, 1997, the state land and farm loan office shall be known and referred to as the office of state lands and investments.
  2. The administrative head of the office shall be a director appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the senate. The director shall serve at the pleasure of the governor and may be removed by the governor as provided in W.S. 9-1-202 .
  3. The office of state lands and investments shall consist of the office of the director and shall administer all programs of the board of land commissioners and state loan and investment board.

History. Laws 1992, ch. 55, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 9-2-2013 ; 1997, ch. 195, § 1; 1998, ch. 13, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

This section was enacted as § 9-2-2013 . As a § 9-2-2013 was also enacted by Laws 1992, chs. 42 and 60, this section has been renumbered as § 9-2-2015 . See, also, §§ 9-2-2013 and 9-2-2014 .

Task force. —

Laws 2005, ch. 235, §§ 1 and 2, as amended by Laws 2006, ch. 93, § 1, creates a legislative-executive task force to review funding for the office of state lands and investments' trust programs. The task force is to: (1) familiarize itself with the trust responsibilities of the office of state lands and investments; (2) conduct a comprehensive review of the office of state lands and investments' budget and its expenditures for trust responsibilities to determine if any change to the budgeted funding of the office of state lands and investments' trust responsibilities is necessary; (3) conduct a comprehensive review, by source, of the relationship of administrative costs to revenues of the office of state lands and investments' trust programs to determine if any change to the budgeted funding of the office of state lands and investments' trust responsibilities is necessary; (4) no later than June 1, 2006, prepare and submit a report to the legislature, which details the task force's findings, recommends whether any change in the manner or source of funding for the office of state lands and investments' trust responsibilities is necessary, recommend any preferable alternatives for funding trust responsibilities; and (5) no later than September 1, 2006, recommend to the joint agriculture, public lands and water resources interim committee and the joint appropriations interim committee any statutory changes that may be required to implement the task force's final recommendations. This act terminates April 1, 2007. The act appropriates $30,000 from the general fund to the office of state lands and investments to fund interim meetings and activities of the task force and to contract with appropriate professionals as necessary to complete the duties assigned to the task force. Laws 2006, ch. 93, § 2, appropriates an additional $20,000 to fund interim meetings and activities of the task force and to contract with appropriate professionals as necessary to complete the duties assigned to the task force.

Laws 2005, ch. 235, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 11, 2005.

Laws 2006, ch. 93, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 24, 2006.

§ 9-2-2016. Department of agriculture created; director appointed; structure.

  1. As part of the reorganization of Wyoming state government, there is created the department of agriculture consisting of the existing state department of agriculture, the agricultural mediation board, the wheat marketing commission, the Wyoming beef council, the Wyoming weed and pest council, the board of certification of the Environmental Pesticide Control Act of 1973, the weed and pest board of certification, the interstate agricultural grain marketing commission, the state fair advisory board and all programs and functions specified in titles 11 and 35 and otherwise under law relating to agriculture and livestock. Except for W.S. 9-2-1703(a)(v) and (ix), the limitation of number of principal departments in W.S. 9-2-1704(a) and 9-2-1707 (a)(iii) and (iv), the provisions of the Wyoming Government Reorganization Act of 1989, W.S. 9-2-1701 through 9-2-1707 , apply to this section.
  2. The administrative head of the department shall be a director who shall serve at the pleasure of the governor and may be removed by him as provided in W.S. 9-1-202 . The director shall be appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the senate.
  3. The department shall not be subject to a transition period as defined in W.S. 9-2-1703(a)(ix). A reorganization plan shall not be required of the director.

History. Laws 1993, ch. 191, § 2; 2008, ch. 116, § 1.

The 2008 amendment, substituted “9-2-1707” for “9-2-1708” in (a).

Laws 2008, ch. 116, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

Task Force. —

Laws 2006, ch. 91, § 1, creates an executive task force for the study of Wyoming bio-security laboratory issues and to coordinate between Wyoming and other state and federal agencies.

Laws 2006, ch. 91, § 2, appropriates one hundred thousand dollars to the Wyoming department of agriculture to fund interim meetings and activities of the task force.

§ 9-2-2017. Department of state parks and cultural resources created; director appointed; structure.

  1. There is created the Wyoming department of state parks and cultural resources consisting of the agencies, programs and functions specified in this section.
  2. The administrative head of the department shall be a director appointed by the governor not later than July 1, 1999, with the advice and consent of the senate. The director may, with the approval of the governor, appoint administrators for each of the divisions. The governor may remove the director and division administrators as provided in W.S. 9-1-202 . The director may employ professional, technical and other assistants to work in the director’s office or in any of the divisions, along with other employees, as authorized by the legislature, to carry out the duties of the department.
  3. The following agencies are assigned to the department of state parks and cultural resources under a Type 1 transfer:
    1. The division of state parks and historic sites from the department of commerce;
    2. The parks and cultural resources commission;
    3. The division of cultural resources from the department of commerce;
    4. The Wyoming council on the arts from the department of commerce;
    5. The division of administrative services from the department of commerce;
    6. The Wyoming pioneer memorial museum from the department of agriculture.
  4. As used in this section:
    1. “Commerce” means the department of commerce;
    2. “Governor” means the office of the governor;
    3. “State parks and cultural resources” means the department of state parks and cultural resources created by this section.
  5. The following divisions are created within the department of state parks and cultural resources:
    1. Division of parks and historic sites;
    2. Division of cultural resources.

History. Laws 1999, ch. 69, § 1; 2000, ch. 48, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

Laws 2007, ch. 25, §§ 1, 2, directed and authorized the board of land commissioners to convey its right, title and interest, in described parcels of land to the department of state parks and cultural resources and the game and fish commission. There was appropriated an amount not to exceed six million dollars ($6,000,000.00) from the budget reserve account to the state land board for the period beginning with the effective date of the act and ending June 30, 2008 for purposes of funding the purchases.

§ 9-2-2018. Department of workforce services created; director appointed; structure.

  1. As part of the reorganization of Wyoming state government, there is created the Wyoming department of workforce services. The provisions of the Wyoming Government Reorganization Act of 1989, W.S. 9-2-1701 through 9-2-1707 apply to this section, except the requirement under W.S. 9-2-1707 (a)(iii) that public hearings regarding the reorganization plan required under subsection (b) of this section be conducted by at least two (2) interim committees of the legislature shall not apply.
  2. The administrative head of the department shall be a director appointed by the governor.
  3. The department reorganization plan shall consider whether the following functions or programs are assigned from or to the agency or department specified under a Type 2 transfer:

    PROGRAM; FROM; TO

    1. Displaced worker education and training; Employment; Workforce services
    2. Division of vocational rehabilitation; Employment; Workforce services
    3. Public employment offices; Employment; Workforce services
    4. Veterans’ employment services; Employment; Workforce services
    5. Unemployment insurance program; Employment; Workforce services
    6. Repealed by Laws 2006, ch. 11, § 2.
    7. Senior community service employment program; Health; Workforce services
    8. Wyoming school-to-careers program; Employment; Workforce services
    9. Personal opportunities with employment responsibilities (POWER) program; Family services; Workforce services
    10. Workforce development training fund; Employment; Workforce services
    11. Supplemental nutrition assistance employment program; Family services; Workforce services
    12. Other programs that may be identified that may improve customer satisfaction or reduce program delivery costs.
  4. As used in this section:
    1. “Community college commission” means the community college commission of Wyoming;
    2. “Education” means the department of education;
    3. “Employment” means the department of employment;
    4. “Family services” means the department of family services;
    5. “Governor” means the office of the governor;
    6. “Health” means the department of health;
    7. “Workforce services” means the department of workforce services created by this section.
  5. In developing the plan required under W.S. 9-2-1707(a)(iii), the director shall consider:
    1. The cost-effectiveness of any recommended transfer;
    2. Whether the recommended transfer will result in a more efficient provision of service to customers;
    3. The extent to which the recommended transfer would benefit from involvement by the Wyoming business council;
    4. Developing a system that will adequately serve customers in both urban and rural areas;
    5. Recommending legislation necessary to allow data sharing for the purpose of evaluating programs and the sharing of a common intake and management information system;
    6. Identifying outcome-based data for all workforce programs, including those programs not proposed for transfer to the department of workforce services under this section;
    7. Developing memoranda of understanding for confidentiality of information and data sharing.
  6. To the extent not prohibited by federal law, any agency or program of the state may provide information to the director as necessary to develop the plan required under W.S. 9-2-1707(a)(iii).
  7. The governor may:
    1. Eliminate any council or commission within the department which is not created under state law if no longer required as a condition to receiving federal funds or if no longer necessary to conform with federal law or regulations;
    2. Consolidate any council or commission within the department which is required in accordance with federal law, but not created under state law, with any other council or commission if the consolidation does not violate federal law or regulations.
  8. Information obtained by any division in the department may be transferred to other divisions within the department so long as the transfer is not restricted by federal law, rule or contract. Such information shall not be disclosed outside of the department except as otherwise provided by law. Any employee who discloses information outside of the department in violation of federal or state law may be terminated without progressive discipline.

History. Laws 2001, ch. 187, § 1; 2006, ch. 11, § 2; 2008, ch. 44, § 1; ch. 116, § 1; 2012, ch. 1, § 1; 2013, ch. 193, § 1.

The 2006 amendment, effective July 1, 2006, repealed former (c)(vi), which read: “Adult education and literacy; Community college commission; Workforce services.”

The 2008 amendments. —

The first 2008 amendment, by ch. 44, § 1, in (b), deleted “not later than July 1, 1990” at the end of the first sentence, and deleted the former second through sixth sentences pertaining to various reporting requirements to the legislature and legislative committees; and in (e)(vi), deleted “Upon approval of the plan by the legislature, the director shall submit a report to the governor and the joint labor, health and social services interim committee no later than October 1 of each year thereafter addressing the results of such program evaluations;” and made a stylistic change.

Laws 2008, ch. 44, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2008.

The second 2008 amendment, by ch. 116, § 1, substituted “9-2-1707” for “9-2-1708” in (a).

Laws 2008, ch. 116, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

The 2012 amendment, effective July 1, 2012, added (g) and (h).

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, substituted “Supplemental nutrition assistance employment program” for “Food stamp employment program” in (c)(xi).

Editor's note. —

Laws 2006, ch. 11, § 3, states: “Effective July 1, 2006, the adult basic education program and the general educational development program shall be transferred from the department of workforce services to the community college commission. All positions, property and appropriated funds associated with these programs shall be transferred from the department to the commission. In addition, all rules and regulations promulgated by the department pertaining to both programs shall remain in effect and unaltered as rules and regulations of the commission until amended or repealed by the commission.”

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2008, ch. 44, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

§ 9-2-2019. Department of enterprise technology services created.

As part of the reorganization of Wyoming state government, there is created the department of enterprise technology services consisting of the existing division of information technology within the department of administration and information and the position and office of state chief information officer. The department shall not be subject to a transition period as defined in W.S. 9-2-1703(a)(ix). A reorganization plan shall not be required of the director.

History. Laws 2012, ch. 30, § 2.

Effective date. —

Laws 2012, ch. 30, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 8, 2012.

§ 9-2-2020. State construction department created.

As part of the reorganization of Wyoming state government, there is created the state construction department consisting of the existing construction management program within the department of administration and information, associated construction management functions of the department of administration and information, and the school facilities department. The state construction department shall not be subject to a transition period as defined in W.S. 9-2-1703(a)(ix). A reorganization plan shall not be required of the director.

History. Laws 2016, ch. 105, § 2.

Effective date. — Laws 2016, ch. 105, § 5, makes the act effective July 1, 2016.

§ 9-2-2021. State budget department created; director appointed; structure.

  1. As part of the reorganization of Wyoming state government, there is created the state budget department consisting of the existing budget division of the department of administration and information. Except as otherwise provided in this section, the provisions of the Wyoming Government Reorganization Act of 1989, W.S. 9-2-1701 through 9-2-1707 , shall apply to this section.
  2. The administrative head of the department shall be a director appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the senate. Not later than May 1, 2020, the governor shall appoint a director in accordance with W.S. 28-12-101 (b). Thereafter, appointments for the director of the state budget department shall be in accordance with W.S. 28-12-101 through 28-12-103 .
  3. Not later than August 15, 2020, the director shall prepare a plan for reorganization of the agencies, programs and functions specified in this section and submit it to the governor for approval. The director shall include in the reorganization plan recommendations regarding any necessary modifications to state budgeting statutes and other statutes relating to the duties of the state budget department.
  4. After the governor approves the plan for reorganization developed pursuant to this section:
    1. The governor shall, when he deems appropriate, set a schedule for implementation of the reorganization plan;
    2. The joint appropriations committee shall develop any necessary legislation with respect to the plan and monitor the state budget department’s work and progress.
  5. Upon submission of the reorganization plan developed pursuant to this section, the state budget department shall have authority provided by law to the budget division within the department of administration and information and shall operate independently of the department of administration and information.
  6. The state budget department shall be subject to the direction of the existing administrator of the budget division of the department of administration and information who shall serve as the director of the state budget department until the governor appoints a director in accordance with this section.
  7. Repealed by Laws 2021, ch. 56, § 5.
  8. The budget division of the department of administration and information is assigned to the state budget department under a Type 1 transfer, effective upon the appointment of a director of the state budget department.
  9. The governor may allocate personnel and other resources between the department of administration and information and the state budget department in accordance with a Type 1 transfer. Nothing in this subsection shall authorize the state budget department to gain positions or funds in addition to the positions and funds currently allocated to the budget division of the department of administration and information.
  10. Upon the appointment of a director of the state budget department, the state budget department shall pursue state savings and efficiency initiatives identified in 2017 Wyoming Session Laws, Chapter 183 and 2018 Wyoming Session Laws, Chapter 112 and identified by the government efficiency commission created by 2017 Wyoming Session Laws, Chapter 183 and continued by 2018 Wyoming Session Laws, Chapter 112.

History. Laws 2020, ch. 115, § 1; 2021, ch. 56, § 5.

The 2021 amendment repealed (g), which read, "The director of the state budget department shall have the authority to: (i) Employ professional, technical and other assistants to work in the director’s office, along with other employees necessary to carry out the purpose of this act; (ii) Adopt reasonable rules and regulations to administer this section pursuant to the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act; (iii) Formulate through his office the policies and programs to be carried out by the department."

Laws 2021, ch. 56, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved April 1, 2021.

Effective date. — Laws 2020, ch. 115, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 17, 2020.

Article 21. Department of Family Services

  • § 9-2-2101.  Department of family services; duties and responsibilities; state grants; authority to contract for shelters; definitions; youth programs. [Effective until July 1, 2021]
  • § 9-2-2101.  Department of family services; duties and responsibilities; state grants; authority to contract for shelters; definitions; youth programs. [Effective July 1, 2021]
  • § 9-2-2102.  Division administrators; appointment.
  • § 9-2-2103.  Allocation, transfer and abolition of powers, duties and functions within department.
  • § 9-2-2104.  Duties and powers of director of department.
  • § 9-2-2105.  Director of department; appointment; removal; duties.
  • § 9-2-2106.  Departmental advisory council; created; term; composition; meetings; removal of members; selection of officers; vacancies; expenses.

Appropriations. —

Laws 2007, Ch. 209, § 2 states as follows: “There is authorized four (4) additional full-time positions to the department of family services. For the purposes of this act there is appropriated from the general fund four hundred eighty thousand dollars ($480,000.00) to the department of family services for the fiscal period beginning July 1, 2007 and ending June 30, 2008.”

§ 9-2-2101. Department of family services; duties and responsibilities; state grants; authority to contract for shelters; definitions; youth programs. [Effective until July 1, 2021]

  1. The department of family services is created. The department of family services is the state youth services authority and the authority for public assistance and social services.
  2. The department shall develop and administer a state program to provide shelter care for youth.
  3. The department shall administer a comprehensive state program for community services for youth which shall include the following:
    1. A coordinated network of services by contracting for shelter services on a regional basis and for juvenile community alternatives on a county basis either through a contract with the county commissioners or through a contract with a single organization designated by the county commissioners. Contracting agencies may establish subcontracts in order to provide those services required by the department. All contracts purchasing services prepared by the department shall provide for periodic program and fiscal review of the operations and expenditure of state funds by the person or organization with whom the department has contracted. All contracts shall be terminated within sixty (60) days upon the occurrence of one (1) of the following unless the deficiency is corrected to the satisfaction of the department:
      1. If the person or organization will not allow on site inspections and review of the programs purchased;
      2. If misuse of state funds is found; or
      3. If the program is not of an acceptable standard or quality.
    2. Minimum standards and policies and procedures for the establishment and operation of the community services for youth;
    3. Rules for the granting of contracts;
    4. Monitoring regional shelter services facilities a minimum of once a year and state funded juvenile community services at least once every three (3) years.
  4. In order to receive juvenile community alternative funds a county shall submit a plan to the department developed by representatives of public and private providers who provide services to troubled youth in the county. The plan shall be in accordance with rules and regulations established by the department. At a minimum the plan shall include:
    1. Identification of gaps in services to troubled youth in the county and an explanation of the proposed projects;
    2. Goals and objectives that will enable the department to monitor the activities that are funded, the number of children and families served and the outcomes achieved;
    3. A demonstration of a commitment to keep youth in the home and community and to work with the family either with community alternative funds or through other funding;
    4. Cooperative agreements among participating agencies which outline the activities to be undertaken by each agency to achieve the goals of the plan.
  5. The purposes of the community services for youth program are to:
    1. Work on the immediate problems of troubled youth in Wyoming communities;
    2. Work with children and families to encourage the resolution of intrafamily problems through counseling and other services;
    3. Work on reuniting youth with their families in cases where the child has been placed out of the home and where additional work needs to be done in order for the youth to be reintegrated into the family;
    4. Strengthen family relationships and promote stable living conditions for troubled youth;
    5. Help youth decide on a future course of action;
    6. Provide appropriate alternatives to involvement in the correctional system.
  6. Community services for youth may include treatment services either directly or through contracts with other agencies.
  7. In order to qualify for funding under this section, a shelter services provider shall:
    1. House no more than ten (10) children together within one (1) facility. This paragraph shall not:
      1. Limit the number of children who may be served in a region; or
      2. If requested by any local authority, prohibit a provider from providing temporary emergency shelter within one (1) facility to more than ten (10) children under the age of eighteen (18) years for not more than seventy-two (72) consecutive hours.
    2. Develop individualized programming for children receiving shelter services for thirty (30) days or less which shall be distinct from individualized programming for children who are expected to receive shelter services for longer than thirty (30) days.
  8. As used in this section:
    1. “Community services for youth” means shelter services and juvenile community alternatives;
    2. “Juvenile community alternatives” means projects which use existing services in a county to divert juveniles from approved correctional programs until no other solution can be determined suitable;
    3. “Shelter services” means residential services for children through eighteen (18) years of age which shall include:
      1. Temporary shelter;
      2. Crisis counseling;
      3. Family involvement;
      4. Aftercare;
      5. Individualized programming for each child.
  9. If there is an existing shelter in a community that meets the criteria for placement of youth as specified in this section and is sufficient to meet the needs of the community, additional shelters shall not be acquired or constructed.
  10. The department shall administer the low income home energy assistance program in accordance with W.S. 42-2-501 .

History. Laws 1991, ch. 161, § 2; 1993, ch. 1, § 1; 2006, ch. 21, § 1; ch. 81, § 2; 2021, ch. 7, § 1.

The 2006 amendments. —

The first 2006 amendment, by ch. 21, § 1, effective July 1, 2006, in (c)(i), in the first sentence, deleted “through a nonprofit board” following “regional basis” and deleted “nonprofit” following “single.”

The second 2006 amendment, by ch. 81, § 2, added (k).

Laws 2006, ch. 81, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 23, 2006.

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

The 2021 amendment, effective July 1, 2021, in (c), added "Subject to the availability of funds" at the beginning, and made a related change.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (i) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Plan for children and families. —

Laws 2004, ch. 44, § 1, provides:

“(a) The department of family services shall develop a comprehensive plan to improve the lives and futures of all children and families in Wyoming. In developing the plan, the department shall collaborate with the business councils of the Northern Arapaho tribe and Eastern Shoshone tribe, state and local agencies, including the department of health, the department of workforce services, the department of employment, the department of education, the department of corrections, the Wyoming business council, the University of Wyoming, Wyoming community colleges, the judiciary and private groups, service providers and businesses, including faith-based organizations and not-for-profit organizations, that express an interest in participating in the development of the plan. The plan shall:

“(i) Consider development of mechanisms to employ the use of public and private resources in an efficient manner to meet the needs of children and families;

“(ii) Include life span recommendations, including, in particular, prenatal and early childhood intervention and development practices that promote meaningful lifetime changes and minimize delays in life skills development;

“(iii) Review the current judicial system and make recommendations for reforms that may enable courts to better meet the needs of children and families;

“(iv) Examine how schools, community organizations, state agencies and the judicial system can work more closely together to enhance a sharing of resources and information to meet the needs of parents, preschool children and elementary and secondary school students;

“(v) Examine causes of the most serious problems facing children and families, including poverty, mental health needs, violence, the lack of adequate health care, the use of tobacco and illegal drugs and the abuse of alcohol;

“(vi) Examine issues of parent accountability;

“(vii) Encourage and support family stability;

“(viii) Not discriminate against private service providers in favor of governmental providers; and

“(ix) Review the state's existing efforts to determine where present funding and human resources could be employed in a more client-centered and efficient manner.

“(b) The department of family services shall submit a preliminary plan with recommendations for any initial legislation to the joint labor, health and social services interim committee no later than November 1, 2004. The final plan shall be submitted no later than October 1, 2005. Any recommendations contained in the plan shall be science-based or reflect practices that have a record of success. The plan shall specifically include recommendations:

“(i) For institutionalizing collaboration among state and local agencies and the private sector, including the business and faith community to provide seamless and integrated services in which funding is blended, when appropriate, to support client-centered plans that meet the needs of individual children and families;

“(ii) For addressing gaps or deficiencies in services;

“(iii) For early intervention and other services that seek to strengthen the bond between children and parents and place the primary responsibility for raising children on the family;

“(iv) For the consolidation of programs or funding sources where appropriate;

“(v) For the development of comprehensive, integrated state and community level approaches that will leave no child unsupported in critical aspects of life, particularly from birth through five (5) years of age;

“(vi) That will result in more integrated, efficient and effective programs and cost savings.

“(c) The department shall widely disseminate requests, including through electronic media, for the active participation of private groups and organizations in the development of the plans. Before submitting the preliminary and final plans to the joint labor, health and social services interim committee, the department shall issue drafts of the plans for public review and hold at least one (1) public meeting in a central location in the state to receive public comments on each plan.

“(d) In addition to the appropriation contained in subsection (e) of this section, the department of family services, the department of health, the department of workforce services, the department of employment, the department of education, the department of corrections, the Wyoming business council, the University of Wyoming, Wyoming community colleges and the judiciary may utilize existing resources and apply for any federal or private grants that may be available to augment funding for the study and plan required under this act. The department may also contract with recognized experts and consultants to conduct the study and develop the plan and recommendations required by this act.

“(e) There is appropriated from the general fund to the department of family services two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) to implement the purposes of this act.”

Laws 2004, ch. 44, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2004.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 3, provides: “[A]ny other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Authority to petition for termination of parental rights. —

Department of Family Services (DFS), a public social service agency, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 9-2-2101(a), with authority to oversee the custody and care of children in cases of abuse and neglect under the Child Protection Act, Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 14-3-401 through 14-3-441 , was an “authorized agency” under Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 14-2-308 and 14-2-310 with authority to file a petition to terminate a mother's parental rights, even though DFS did not have custody of the children. State v. DH (In the Interest of LB), 2014 WY 10, 316 P.3d 1184, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 2014).

§ 9-2-2101. Department of family services; duties and responsibilities; state grants; authority to contract for shelters; definitions; youth programs. [Effective July 1, 2021]

  1. The department of family services is created. The department of family services is the state youth services authority and the authority for public assistance and social services.
  2. The department shall develop and administer a state program to provide shelter care for youth.
  3. Subject to the availability of funds, the department shall administer a comprehensive state program for community services for youth which shall include the following:
    1. A coordinated network of services by contracting for shelter services on a regional basis and for juvenile community alternatives on a county basis either through a contract with the county commissioners or through a contract with a single organization designated by the county commissioners. Contracting agencies may establish subcontracts in order to provide those services required by the department. All contracts purchasing services prepared by the department shall provide for periodic program and fiscal review of the operations and expenditure of state funds by the person or organization with whom the department has contracted. All contracts shall be terminated within sixty (60) days upon the occurrence of one (1) of the following unless the deficiency is corrected to the satisfaction of the department:
      1. If the person or organization will not allow on site inspections and review of the programs purchased;
      2. If misuse of state funds is found; or
      3. If the program is not of an acceptable standard or quality.
    2. Minimum standards and policies and procedures for the establishment and operation of the community services for youth;
    3. Rules for the granting of contracts;
    4. Monitoring regional shelter services facilities a minimum of once a year and state funded juvenile community services at least once every three (3) years.
  4. In order to receive juvenile community alternative funds a county shall submit a plan to the department developed by representatives of public and private providers who provide services to troubled youth in the county. The plan shall be in accordance with rules and regulations established by the department. At a minimum the plan shall include:
    1. Identification of gaps in services to troubled youth in the county and an explanation of the proposed projects;
    2. Goals and objectives that will enable the department to monitor the activities that are funded, the number of children and families served and the outcomes achieved;
    3. A demonstration of a commitment to keep youth in the home and community and to work with the family either with community alternative funds or through other funding;
    4. Cooperative agreements among participating agencies which outline the activities to be undertaken by each agency to achieve the goals of the plan.
  5. The purposes of the community services for youth program are to:
    1. Work on the immediate problems of troubled youth in Wyoming communities;
    2. Work with children and families to encourage the resolution of intrafamily problems through counseling and other services;
    3. Work on reuniting youth with their families in cases where the child has been placed out of the home and where additional work needs to be done in order for the youth to be reintegrated into the family;
    4. Strengthen family relationships and promote stable living conditions for troubled youth;
    5. Help youth decide on a future course of action;
    6. Provide appropriate alternatives to involvement in the correctional system.
  6. Community services for youth may include treatment services either directly or through contracts with other agencies.
  7. In order to qualify for funding under this section, a shelter services provider shall:
    1. House no more than ten (10) children together within one (1) facility. This paragraph shall not:
      1. Limit the number of children who may be served in a region; or
      2. If requested by any local authority, prohibit a provider from providing temporary emergency shelter within one (1) facility to more than ten (10) children under the age of eighteen (18) years for not more than seventy-two (72) consecutive hours.
    2. Develop individualized programming for children receiving shelter services for thirty (30) days or less which shall be distinct from individualized programming for children who are expected to receive shelter services for longer than thirty (30) days.
  8. As used in this section:
    1. “Community services for youth” means shelter services and juvenile community alternatives;
    2. “Juvenile community alternatives” means projects which use existing services in a county to divert juveniles from approved correctional programs until no other solution can be determined suitable;
    3. “Shelter services” means residential services for children through eighteen (18) years of age which shall include:
      1. Temporary shelter;
      2. Crisis counseling;
      3. Family involvement;
      4. Aftercare;
      5. Individualized programming for each child.
  9. If there is an existing shelter in a community that meets the criteria for placement of youth as specified in this section and is sufficient to meet the needs of the community, additional shelters shall not be acquired or constructed.
  10. The department shall administer the low income home energy assistance program in accordance with W.S. 42-2-501 .

History. Laws 1991, ch. 161, § 2; 1993, ch. 1, § 1; 2006, ch. 21, § 1; ch. 81, § 2; 2021, ch. 7, § 1.

§ 9-2-2102. Division administrators; appointment.

The director shall appoint a separate administrator for each of the divisions of the department of family services and he may discharge the administrators as provided in W.S. 9-2-1706(c)(ii).

History. Laws 1991, ch. 161, § 2.

§ 9-2-2103. Allocation, transfer and abolition of powers, duties and functions within department.

The governor may, after consultation with the director of the department and the departmental advisory council designate the department as the single state agency for the administration of state plans for public assistance and social assistance to administer upon such terms as the governor directs.

History. Laws 1991, ch. 161, § 2.

§ 9-2-2104. Duties and powers of director of department.

  1. The director shall:
    1. Consult with the departmental advisory council and establish general policy to be followed in the department in administering programs;
    2. Disburse and administer all federal funds or other monies allotted to the department;
    3. Prescribe by rule, order or regulation the conditions under which these monies shall be disbursed and administered. Any audit performed shall comply with the requirements of W.S. 9-1-507 ;
    4. Enter into agreements, not inconsistent with the laws of this state, required as conditions precedent to receiving funds or other assistance. Funds appropriated by the legislature for operation of the department shall be used for the specified purposes only, and the director, in accepting funds from any other source, shall not consent to impairment of the department’s statutory responsibilities;
    5. Hold hearings, administer oaths, subpoena witnesses and take testimony as provided by the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act in all matters relating to the exercise and performance of the powers and duties vested in the department;
    6. With the assistance of the attorney general bring actions in the courts of the state in the name of the department for the enforcement of public welfare laws;
    7. Promulgate reasonable rules and regulations in compliance with the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act, for the implementation of all state and federal welfare laws;
    8. Appoint and prescribe the duties of the superintendent of the Wyoming boys’ school and the superintendent of the Wyoming girls’ school. Each superintendent shall be under the direct authority and control of the director and may be removed by the director at any time without cause;
    9. Ensure all rules and other written statements of policy or interpretation formulated or adopted by the department use language which focuses on the importance of a person, rather than a person’s disability.
  2. Notwithstanding paragraph (a)(iv) of this section, the director may use funds appropriated by the legislature for the operation of the department to pay health or medical insurance premiums for any resident of Wyoming upon a determination by the director or his designee that:
    1. Due to an injury or illness, the person or his family is or may become unable to pay health or medical insurance premiums;
    2. The person is or may become eligible for medical services which would be paid for by the state; and
    3. Payment of the premiums may be less expensive for the state than payment of the medical services.
  3. Health or medical insurance premiums paid for in accordance with subsection (b) of this section shall be reviewed periodically to ensure payment of the premiums does not exceed the cost for provision of medical services. The authority granted under subsection (b) of this section shall terminate effective June 30, 1996.

History. Laws 1991, ch. 161, § 2; 1994, ch. 9, § 1; 1995, ch. 199, § 1; 1996, ch. 13, § 1; 1998, ch. 7, § 1; 2008, ch. 70, § 1; ch. 116, § 1; 2010, ch. 82, § 1.

The 2008 amendments. —

The first 2008 amendment, by ch. 70, § 1, added (a)(ix).

Laws 2008, ch. 70, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 7, 2008.

The second 2008 amendment, by ch. 116, § 1, made stylistic changes.

Laws 2008, ch. 116, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2008.

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

The 2010 amendment, made a stylistic change.

Laws 2010, ch. 82, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 9, 2010.

Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. —

See § 16-3-101(a), (b)(xi).

Construction. —

There was nothing in language of former subdivision (a)(viii) of this section that accorded superintendent of Wyoming boys' school permanent status; amendment of that provision to add at-will employment language therefore did not amount to breach of an implied contract. Renaud v. Wyoming Dep't of Family Servs., 203 F.3d 723, 2000 U.S. App. LEXIS 1672 (10th Cir. Wyo. 2000).

Stated in

RM v. Department of Family Servs., 953 P.2d 477, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1998).

§ 9-2-2105. Director of department; appointment; removal; duties.

With the advice and consent of the senate the governor shall appoint a director for the department who shall serve under the direction of the governor and who may be removed by the governor as provided in W.S. 9-1-202 . Appointments and terms under this section shall be in accordance with W.S. 28-12-101 through 28-12-103 .

History. Laws 1991, ch. 161, § 2.

§ 9-2-2106. Departmental advisory council; created; term; composition; meetings; removal of members; selection of officers; vacancies; expenses.

  1. There is created within the department an advisory council of not more than sixteen (16) members. Each member shall serve a three (3) year term, except legislators shall serve only for the term of office during which they were appointed. The council shall include:
    1. One (1) member of the senate appointed by the president of the senate;
    2. One (1) member of the house of representatives appointed by the speaker of the house of representatives;
    3. Not more than fourteen (14) members appointed by the governor to represent the interests of the public and the department.
  2. The departmental advisory council shall meet at least three (3) times each year.
  3. The governor may remove any member of the departmental advisory council, except those appointed from the legislature, as provided in W.S. 9-1-202 .
  4. At the first meeting of the departmental advisory council, and annually thereafter when new appointments are made, a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary shall be selected from among the membership by vote of the council members.
  5. Vacancies on the departmental advisory council shall be filled by the appointing authority for the unexpired term.
  6. Members of the departmental advisory council shall not receive compensation for their services, but when actually engaged in the performance of their duties, they shall receive travel expenses, per diem and mileage expenses in the same manner and amount as employees of the state.

History. Laws 1991, ch. 161, § 2.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, construction, and application of Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 (FERPA) (20 USC § 1232g), 112 ALR Fed 1.

Article 22. Office of Administrative Hearings

  • § 9-2-2201.  Office created; appointment of director and hearing examiners.
  • § 9-2-2202.  Duties and function of office.
  • § 9-2-2203.  Rulemaking authority.

§ 9-2-2201. Office created; appointment of director and hearing examiners.

  1. The office of administrative hearings is created as a separate operating agency pursuant to W.S. 9-2-1704(d).
  2. The governor, with the advice and consent of the senate, shall appoint a director of the office who shall serve as the administrative head of the office and as chief hearing examiner. Unless sooner removed, the director’s term of appointment expires at the end of the term of office of the governor during which he was appointed. The director serves at the pleasure of the governor and may be removed by him as provided by W.S. 9-1-202 . The director shall be a member in good standing of the Wyoming state bar.
  3. The director may appoint additional hearing examiners who are members in good standing of the Wyoming state bar to serve either full or part time as necessary throughout the state. Hearing examiners serve at the pleasure of the director and may be removed by him at any time without cause.

History. Laws 1992, ch. 30, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to hearings on driver's license suspension for nonpayment of child support, see § 20-6-111 .

Cited in

State Transp. Comm'n v. Ford, 844 P.2d 496, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 208 (Wyo. 1992).

§ 9-2-2202. Duties and function of office.

  1. The office of administrative hearings is the successor agency to the office of independent hearing examiners created by W.S. 27-14-602 and the office of hearing examiners created by W.S. 31-7-105 . Effective July 1, 1992:
    1. There is transferred to the office of administrative hearings all positions, personnel, property and appropriated funds of the office of independent hearing examiners and the office of hearing examiners;
    2. The office of administrative hearings shall assume all duties and responsibilities and exercise all authority of the office of independent hearing examiners and the office of hearing examiners set out in title 27, chapter 14 and title 31, chapters 6, 7, 9 and 17 of the Wyoming statutes.
  2. In addition to conducting hearings pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, the office of administrative hearings may, if requested, provide hearing services for any other state agency, provided:
    1. Hearing services shall be provided to other agencies subject to available resources;
    2. The cost of the hearing services as determined by the director of the office of administrative hearings shall be paid by the requesting agency to the office of administrative hearings;
    3. Hearings will be conducted in an impartial manner pursuant to the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act, applicable provisions of the Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure and any rules for the conduct of contested cases adopted by the director of the office of administrative hearings which shall take precedence over hearing rules promulgated by the requesting agency. In the case of personnel hearings conducted pursuant to W.S. 9-2-3206 , the state personnel rules shall govern the conduct of the hearings;
    4. Hearings may be held in any area of the state giving consideration to the resources of the office of administrative hearings and the convenience of the parties.

History. Laws 1992, ch. 30, § 1; 1997, ch. 88, § 1; 2021, ch. 56, § 3.

The 2021 amendment substituted "9-2-3206" for "9-2-1019" in the second sentence of (b)(iii).

Laws 2021, ch. 56, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved April 1, 2021.

§ 9-2-2203. Rulemaking authority.

The director of the office of administrative hearings shall promulgate reasonable rules and regulations necessary to carry out the functions and responsibilities assigned to the office.

History. Laws 1992, ch. 30, § 1.

Article 23. Wyoming Cultural Trust Fund

  • § 9-2-2301.  Short title.
  • § 9-2-2302.  Legislative declaration.
  • § 9-2-2303.  Definitions.
  • § 9-2-2304.  Wyoming cultural trust fund established; corpus inviolate; investment by state treasurer. [Effective until July 1, 2021]
  • § 9-2-2304.  Wyoming cultural trust fund established; corpus inviolate; investment by state treasurer. [Effective July 1, 2021]
  • § 9-2-2305.  Wyoming cultural trust fund board; creation; members.
  • § 9-2-2306.  Wyoming cultural trust fund board; duties and responsibilities.
  • § 9-2-2307.  Disbursement of grants from trust fund investment earnings.
  • § 9-2-2308.  Biennial audit; report by board.

§ 9-2-2301. Short title.

This article shall be known and may be cited as the “Wyoming Cultural Trust Fund Act.”

History. Laws 1998, ch. 79, § 1.

§ 9-2-2302. Legislative declaration.

  1. The legislature hereby finds that Wyoming and its people possess a unique cultural heritage. The legislature further finds that there is a need to preserve, promote and enhance that unique cultural heritage for the citizens of the state and the nation and for future generations to understand and appreciate the heritage that makes Wyoming unique among the United States.
  2. It is the purpose of this article to promote, preserve and enhance Wyoming’s unique cultural heritage by creating a Wyoming cultural trust fund administered by a trust fund board to coordinate public and private donations and manage the distribution of the investment earnings from the Wyoming cultural trust fund.

History. Laws 1998, ch. 79, § 1.

§ 9-2-2303. Definitions.

  1. As used in this article:
    1. “Board” means the Wyoming cultural trust fund board established by W.S. 9-2-2305 ;
    2. “Division” means the division of cultural resources within the department of state parks and cultural resources, or its successor;
    3. “Trust fund” means the Wyoming cultural trust fund created by W.S. 9-2-2304 .

History. Laws 1998, ch. 79, § 1; 1999, ch. 69, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 9-2-2304. Wyoming cultural trust fund established; corpus inviolate; investment by state treasurer. [Effective until July 1, 2021]

  1. The Wyoming cultural trust fund is created. The Wyoming cultural trust fund shall consist of those funds designated to the fund by law and all monies collected from federal grants and other contributions, grants, gifts, bequests and donations to the cultural trust fund.
  2. The monies deposited into the Wyoming cultural resources trust fund established pursuant to this section are inviolate and constitute a permanent or perpetual trust fund. The monies shall be transmitted to the state treasurer for credit to the trust fund and shall be invested by the state treasurer as authorized under W.S. 9-4-715(a), (d) and (e) in a manner to obtain the highest return possible consistent with the preservation of the corpus. Any interest earned from investment of the corpus of the trust fund shall be credited by the state treasurer into a separate account and distributed in accordance with W.S. 9-2-2307 .

History. Laws 1998, ch. 79, § 1; 2000, ch. 48, § 2; 2005, ch. 231, § 1; 2008, ch. 113, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005,in (a), rewrote the first sentence, deleting reference to the trust and agency fund, and substituted “fund” for “account”; and deleted reference to the trust and agency fund in (b).

The 2008 amendment, effective July 1, 2008, substituted “W.S. 9-4-715(a), (d) and (e)” for “W.S. 9-4-711 ” in (b).

The 2021 amendment, effective July 1, 2021, in the second sentence of (b), substituted "by law and" for "under W.S. 9-4-715(a), (d) and (e)," added "net" following "highest," and substituted "earnings" for "interest earned" in the third sentence.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2005, ch. 231, § 3, provides: “The provisions of this act shall supersede the provisions of any other bill enacted into law during the 2005 general session which amends or references accounts or funds to the extent any other enactment is inconsistent with the establishment of the funds and accounts created under this act. The state auditor shall account for any fund or account created in any other legislation enacted in the 2005 general session in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) as promulgated by the governmental accounting standards board (GASB) and in accordance with this act.”

§ 9-2-2304. Wyoming cultural trust fund established; corpus inviolate; investment by state treasurer. [Effective July 1, 2021]

  1. The Wyoming cultural trust fund is created. The Wyoming cultural trust fund shall consist of those funds designated to the fund by law and all monies collected from federal grants and other contributions, grants, gifts, bequests and donations to the cultural trust fund.
  2. The monies deposited into the Wyoming cultural resources trust fund established pursuant to this section are inviolate and constitute a permanent or perpetual trust fund. The monies shall be transmitted to the state treasurer for credit to the trust fund and shall be invested by the state treasurer as authorized by law and in a manner to obtain the highest net return possible consistent with the preservation of the corpus. Any earnings from investment of the corpus of the trust fund shall be credited by the state treasurer into a separate account and distributed in accordance with W.S. 9-2-2307 .

History. Laws 1998, ch. 79, § 1; 2000, ch. 48, § 2; 2005, ch. 231, § 1; 2008, ch. 113, § 2; 2021, ch. 108, § 1.

§ 9-2-2305. Wyoming cultural trust fund board; creation; members.

  1. There is created the Wyoming cultural trust fund board. The board shall consist of six (6) members, as follows:
    1. The administrator of the division of cultural resources or his designee who shall serve as an ex officio member of the board, without a vote; and
    2. Five (5) persons who are residents of Wyoming, appointed by the governor and confirmed by the senate. Board membership shall reflect a broad spectrum of experiences, including, but not limited to, the arts, history, archaeology, humanities and cultural and heritage tourism and shall be selected from the following nominees:
      1. One (1) person nominated by the Wyoming commission on parks and cultural resources;
      2. Two (2) persons nominated by the Wyoming arts council board; and
      3. Two (2) persons nominated by the Wyoming national register review board.
  2. Except for the initial board, each appointed member of the board shall serve for a term of three (3) years. Of the initial appointees, one (1) member shall be appointed for one (1) year, two (2) members shall be appointed for two (2) years and two (2) members shall be appointed for three (3) years. The governor may remove any member as provided in W.S. 9-1-202 . A vacancy on the board shall be filled for the balance of the unexpired term. The board shall select one (1) of its members to serve as chairman.
  3. The board shall meet regularly. Members shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed for expenses incurred in the performance of their duties in the manner and amounts provided by law for state employees.

History. Laws 1998, ch. 79, § 1; 2009, ch. 101, § 1; 2014, ch. 37, § 1.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in (a)(ii)(B) added “board” following “council.”

The 2014 amendment, effective March 1, 2015, in the introductory paragraph of (a), substituted “six (6)” for “five (5)”; in (a)(i), inserted “who shall serve as an ex officio member of the board, without a vote”; in introductory paragraph of (a)(ii), substituted “Five (5)” for “Four (4),” inserted “who are residents of Wyoming,” inserted “Board membership shall reflect a broad spectrum of experiences, including, but not limited to, the arts, history, archaeology, humanities and cultural and heritage tourism and shall be selected”; in (a)(ii)(A), substituted “One (1) person” for “Two (2) persons”; added (a)(ii)(C); and made stylistic changes.

§ 9-2-2306. Wyoming cultural trust fund board; duties and responsibilities.

  1. The board shall:
    1. Initiate innovative program planning;
    2. Review innovative program grants and grant proposals;
    3. Establish criteria for grant categories and grant applications through rules and regulations;
    4. Require local matching funds or other in-kind contributions from grantees;
    5. Review and monitor the expenditure of monies from the trust fund to grantees; and
    6. Consider other necessary matters.
  2. In fulfilling its duties under subsection (a) of this section, the board may:
    1. Consult with the Wyoming arts council and the Wyoming parks and cultural resources commission as necessary;
    2. Accept federal grants and other contributions, grants, gifts, bequests and donations from any source.
  3. The board shall promulgate reasonable rules and regulations in accordance with the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act to implement the provisions of W.S. 9-2-2301 through 9-2-2308 .

History. Laws 1998, ch. 79, § 1.

Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. —

See § 16-3-101(a), (b)(xi).

§ 9-2-2307. Disbursement of grants from trust fund investment earnings.

  1. Subject to approval of applications from nonprofit and governmental cultural, historical and arts organizations, the board may award grants to promote, preserve and enhance the unique cultural heritage of Wyoming and its people.
  2. The board shall have the discretion in determining the amount of money under each grant, except that no grant shall be awarded until:
    1. The corpus of the trust fund equals four million dollars ($4,000,000.00) or July 1, 2000, whichever occurs earlier; and
    2. The interest earned from the corpus of the fund and available for disbursement is sufficient to adequately fund a project, taking into consideration all other monies or in-kind contributions provided as a match for the project by the grantee.

History. Laws 1998, ch. 79, § 1.

§ 9-2-2308. Biennial audit; report by board.

  1. The director of the department of audit or his designee shall audit the trust fund created by W.S. 9-2-2304 biennially.
  2. The board shall annually report to the governor, the joint appropriations interim committee and the joint travel, recreation, wildlife and cultural resources interim committee no later than October 1 with respect to all:
    1. Federal grants, state appropriations and other contributions, grants, gifts, bequests and donations received and credited to the Wyoming cultural trust fund during the preceding fiscal year; and
    2. Grants awarded by the board to nonprofit and governmental cultural, historical and arts organizations.

History. Laws 1998, ch. 79, § 1; 1999, ch. 150, § 1; 2008, ch. 44, § 1.

The 2008 amendment deleted the former second sentence of (a), which read: “Copies of the audit shall be provided to the governor and the joint travel, recreation, wildlife and cultural resources interim committee.”

Laws 2008, ch. 44, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 5, 2008.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2008, ch. 44, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Article 24. Court Reorganization

  • § 9-2-2401.  [Repealed.]

§ 9-2-2401. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2009, ch. 168, § 205.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1998 ch 109 § 1, related to reorganization plan for courts, purpose, plan and schedule, and establishment of judicial planning commission.

Laws 2009, ch 168, § 602, makes the act effective July 1, 2009.

Article 25. Governmental Electronic Transactions

  • § 9-2-2501.  Director of department of enterprise technology services; duties; electronic transaction of business.

§ 9-2-2501. Director of department of enterprise technology services; duties; electronic transaction of business.

  1. Repealed by Laws 2005 ch. 174, § 3.
  2. The state chief information officer may provide for any state agency business to be conducted electronically in accordance with rules adopted under this section and in conformity with the provisions of the Uniform Electronic Transactions Act in title 40, chapter 21. No state agency shall be required by the chief information officer to conduct business electronically. Any state agency desiring to conduct business electronically shall adopt the procedures contained in rules of the department of enterprise technology services.
  3. The department of enterprise technology services may enact rules the chief information officer deems necessary to implement this section subject to the provisions of the Uniform Electronic Transactions Act in title 40, chapter 21. The rules shall at a minimum:
    1. Establish standards for all state agencies conducting business electronically;
    2. Establish parameters for ensuring security in conducting state agency business electronically;
    3. Establish authorized methods and requirements for conducting business electronically and authenticating identifications. The rules shall require that each individual required by applicable statute or rule to sign any document be specifically identified as acknowledging the document and giving assent to the electronic transmission through a key encryption or other identification procedure unique to that individual;
    4. Prescribe a procedure for certification by a state agency of information transmitted electronically; and
    5. Prescribe a procedure for converting information transmitted electronically to paper and certifying the paper copy for persons requiring paper copies.
  4. In adopting rules the department of enterprise technology services shall consider whether the rule will allow for efficient, safe, secure and accurate transactions.
  5. Notwithstanding any other provision of law requiring a manual or facsimile signature on information filed with a state agency any information filed electronically which meets the requirements of the rules adopted pursuant to this section shall be considered to be lawfully filed with the state agency for all legal purposes if that agency has authorized the electronic filing.
  6. Nothing in this section shall be construed to affect any requirement of statute or rule that a particular individual or officer of an organization acknowledge a document. Any person using a key encryption or other identification procedure in place of a manual or facsimile signature for any filing under this section shall be subject to the same civil and criminal penalties applicable to persons providing a manual or facsimile signature.
  7. A state agency shall not be liable for any loss or damages arising from errors in or omissions from information filed electronically.
  8. No statutory provision which authorizes facsimile or electronic filing with any state agency shall be superseded by this section or any rule of the department adopted pursuant to this section.
  9. As used in this section, “state agency” means any authority, bureau, board, commission, department, division, institution or officer of the state, except the state legislature and the judiciary.

History. Laws 1999, ch. 49, § 1; 2001, ch. 58, § 2; 2005, ch. 174, §§ 2, 3; ch. 230, § 11; ch. 242, § 2; 2012, ch. 30, § 3.

The 2005 amendments. —

The first 2005 amendment, by ch. 174, §§ 2 and 3, effective July 1, 2005, repealed former (a), which created the Wyoming on-line government commission; and substituted “state chief information officer” or “chief information officer” for “commissioner” throughout.

The second 2005 amendment, by ch. 242, § 2, deleted “or their designees” at the end of the first sentence in (a).

Laws 2005, ch. 242, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 11, 2005.

See the conflicting legislation note below. This section is set out pursuant to Laws 2005, ch. 230, § 11, and as directed by the Wyoming legislative service office

The 2012 amendment, substituted “department of enterprise technology services” for “chief information officer” in (b) through (d); substituted “the chief information officer” for “he” in (c); and substituted “department” for “chief information officer” in (h).

Laws 2012, ch. 30, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 8, 2012.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (i) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2004, ch. 230, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Laws 2005, ch. 230, § 11, directs that in the case of conflict, § 9-2-2501(a) as amended by 2005 House Enrolled Act 112, which was enacted as Laws 2005, ch. 242, would not be effective, and § 9-2-2501(a) would be repealed as provided by 2005 Senate Enrolled Act 75, which was enacted as Laws 2005, ch. 174.

Article 26. Department of Workforce Services

  • § 9-2-2601.  Department of workforce services; duties and responsibilities; agreements with other agencies authorized; definition; merger with department of employment.
  • § 9-2-2602.  Director of department; appointment; removal; duties.
  • § 9-2-2603.  [Vetoed.]
  • § 9-2-2604.  Workforce development training fund established.
  • § 9-2-2605.  Sale of office publications; exception.
  • § 9-2-2606.  Sale of office publications; limitation on charges.
  • § 9-2-2607.  Confidentiality of information; disclosure; reimbursement.
  • § 9-2-2608.  Workplace safety contract program.
  • § 9-2-2609.  Purpose.
  • § 9-2-2610.  Definitions.
  • § 9-2-2611.  Priority economic sector business workforce training programs; eligibility.

Editor's notes. —

Both Laws 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 81, § 1, and Laws 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 100, § 1, enacted an article 26 in chapter 2 of this title. The provisions enacted by ch. 81, § 1, have been redesignated as article 27 (§§ 9-2-2701 through 9-2-2707 .)

§ 9-2-2601. Department of workforce services; duties and responsibilities; agreements with other agencies authorized; definition; merger with department of employment.

  1. The department of workforce services is created. The department is the authority for workforce services. The department is the successor agency for public employment and training services which previously existed under the department of employment. The department shall perform all functions previously performed by those programs.
  2. The department may submit a plan for the state to the appropriate federal agencies for work activities and programs as authorized under section 102 of the act of congress approved July 22, 2014 entitled “Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act”, P.L. 113-128, 29 U.S.C. 3112 or subsequent similar enactments.
  3. The department shall adopt rules and regulations pursuant to the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act to implement requirements of the federal Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act or subsequent similar enactments. When adopting such rules and regulations the department shall use language which focuses on the importance of a person, rather than a person’s disability.
  4. The department shall administer expenditures from the workforce development training fund as provided in W.S. 9-2-2604 . The department shall administer expenditures from the Wyoming workforce development-priority economic sector partnership subaccount within the economic diversification account as provided in W.S. 9-2-2609 through 9-2-2611 and 9-12-1404 .
  5. The department is the designated agency for the state under 29 U.S.C. § 49 et seq. and shall:
    1. Comply with the requirements of and secure benefits for the state under 29 U.S.C. § 49 et seq.;
    2. Establish and maintain public employment offices throughout the state; and
    3. Cooperate with federal agencies under 29 U.S.C. § 49 et seq.
  6. The department may cooperate and enter into agreements with the railroad retirement board, any other federal or state agency or any private nonprofit organization for the provision of public employment offices and services and may accept contributions for this purpose.
  7. The department shall take appropriate steps to:
    1. Reduce and prevent unemployment and provide supportive services that are necessary to assist individuals to take part in activities leading to self-sufficiency;
    2. Encourage and assist in the adoption of practical methods of vocational training, retraining and guidance;
    3. Investigate, recommend, advise and assist in the establishment and operation of public works reserves by the state and its political subdivisions to be used in times of business depression and unemployment;
    4. Promote alternative reemployment of unemployed workers throughout the state;
    5. Conduct and publish results of investigations and research studies;
    6. Assist the Wyoming workforce development council and the state youth council in pursuing their missions and goals; and
    7. Administer contracts pursuant to W.S. 9-2-2608 and 9-2-2609 through 9-2-2611 .
  8. In any civil action to enforce this act, the department may be represented by the attorney general at the request of the department.
  9. As used in this article unless the context requires otherwise, “department” means the department of workforce services.
  10. On or before July 1, 2011, the department of workforce services shall include all divisions, programs and functions previously assigned to the department of employment created by W.S. 9-2-2002 .
